newsitem.title: USA: Boyd Gaming $250 mln junk bond deal postponed.
newsitem.headline: Boyd Gaming $250 mln junk bond deal postponed.

text.p: Boyd Gaming Corp has postponed a $250 million junk bond offering becuase it was unsatisfied with the price level available in the market, a Boyd spokesman said.
The company planned to raise $250 million though an offering of senior subordinated notes to refinance debt including $185 million in outstanding 11 percent senior subordinated notes.
A Boyd spokesman said Boyd hopes to raise the funds via a note offering "when pricing makes the most sense for the company." He declined further comment.
Salomon Brothers Inc, the underwriter of the offering, declined to comment.
Market sources said that Boyd had originally hoped to price the 10-year bonds (B1/BB-) around 300 basis points over comparable Treasuries.
It was unable to achieve that price primarily due to poor market conditions created by the recently large number of new junk bond issues, they said.

"Part of this is also a reflection on the gaming sector," said one high-yield bond gaming analyst. "A lot of people recognize that the gaming sector is very rich and very few are willing to put new money to work in it."
The analyst suspected Boyd is likely to reattempt the offering before December 1, 1997, when its 11 percent bonds become callable.
